properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop later tonight and continue until late Friday afternoon. These snow squalls could potentially produce 15 cm of snow within 12 hours. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-19T08:17:44-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-18T16:18:44-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3828439825.2021
Area: Agawa - Lake Superior Park
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls tonight and Friday. Snow squalls have developed between Wawa and Marathon south of Highway 17. The snow squalls are expected to move east into the town of Wawa and the Agawa region overnight. Travel along Highway 17 between Wawa and Agawa Bay may become hazardous overnight and Friday due to heavy snow and poor visibility. Accumulations in excess of 20 cm are possible. The snow squalls are expected to move south of the region late Friday. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-19T12:43:20-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-18T20:44:20-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1555120417.2021

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning Ended
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions have improved for the time being. Buffalo and King City Weather RADARs continue to show a strong band of snow over Lake Ontario...this band will be closely monitored and new alerts may be required tonight. ###

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls today into Friday morning. Snow squalls have begun to develop near Lake Superior and will persist into Friday morning. The strongest activity today is expected between Wawa and Marathon south of Highway 17. The snow squalls may move towards the town of Wawa later tonight into Friday morning. The heaviest accumulations are expected close to the shoreline west of Wawa where amounts may exceed 20 cm. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Accumulating snow is expected for the start of the weekend. Total snowfall: 10 to 20 cm. Locations: southern half of Nova Scotia, including Halifax Metro. Time span: Friday evening until Saturday afternoon. Remarks: Snow will likely begin spreading across western Nova Scotia Friday afternoon, and then across the rest of the province Friday night. The snow will taper off from west to east during the day Saturday. Latest forecast guidance suggests that accumulations of 10 to 20 cm are possible. This system is still in early stages of development. The situation may change and it will continue to be closely monitored as it approaches in the event that warnings may be required. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-19T06:42:39-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-18T14:43:39-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1142078319.2021

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Smog Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High concentrations of pollutants are expected through Friday morning and will result in poor air quality, especially in metropolitan areas where pollutant emissions are more significant. ### Smog especially affects asthmatic children and people with respiratory ailments or heart disease. It is therefore recommended that these individuals avoid intense physical activity outdoors until the smog warning is lifted. In Quebec, wood heating is the main source of fine particles that contribute to smog during winter. This activity generates the largest number of these particulates, more than industrial activities and transportation. Additional information: To learn more about the Info-Smog program, go to Environment Canada’s website at www.canada.ca/info-smog-program. For air quality indexes in Quebec, visit the website of the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques at www.iqa.environnement.gouv.qc.ca/contenu/index_en.asp. For the air quality index in Montréal, visit the Réseau de surveillance de la qualité de l’air de la Ville de Montréal’s website at www.rsqa.qc.ca (french only). To learn more about the effects of smog on your health in Québec, visit the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux’s website at www.quebec.ca/en/health. You can also visit the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal at www.santemontreal.qc.ca/en/public. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2021-02-19T21:59:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques, the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux, the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal, the City of Montréal, 2021-02-19T01:24:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2702911722.2021
Area: La Sarre area, Amos area, Lebel-sur-Quévillon area, Senneterre area, Rouyn area, Malartic area, Val d'Or - Louvicourt area

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for late this afternoon and early this evening. What: Snow. Total amounts near 5 cm are possible by this evening. Where: Southwestern portions of the Durham region, particularly Highway 401 in Pickering and Ajax. When: Now through early evening. Discussion: Lake enhanced snowfall is expected to locally boost snowfall amounts to near 5 cm for areas just east of Toronto. Accumulating snow could cause poor driving conditions, and impact the commute this evening. The band of lake enhanced snow should move westward out of the region this evening. Actions: Drivers should plan to give themselves extra time to reach their destination. If visibility is reduced while driving, slow down, watch for tail lights ahead and be prepared to stop. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-19T06:39:01-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-18T20:53:01-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2208714352.2021
Area: Pickering - Oshawa - Southern Durham Region
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for tonight. What: Snow and poor visibility. Total amounts of 5 to 15 cm are expected by Friday morning. Where: Portions of the Greater Toronto Area, particularly downtown Toronto, southern Etobicoke, Mississauga, Milton, and Oakville. This includes sections of the following highways: -Highway 403 -Highway 407 -Highway 427 -Queen Elizabeth Way -Gardiner Expressway When: Now through Friday morning. The Friday morning commute may be impacted. Discussion: Regional Weather RADAR continues to track a band of heavy snow over Lake Ontario. This band will continue to impact the region tonight. Further snowfall accumulations of up to 10 cm are expected by Friday morning. Remember...the localized nature of lake enhanced snow means that snowfall intensity and accumulations may vary considerably between nearby locations. Actions: Drivers should plan to give themselves extra time to reach their destination. If visibility is reduced while driving, slow down, watch for tail lights ahead and be prepared to stop. See snow go slow! ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-19T15:59:25-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-19T04:01:25-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4172020215.2021
Area: City of Toronto, Mississauga - Brampton, Halton Hills - Milton, Burlington - Oakville

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Accumulating snow is expected for the start of the weekend. Total snowfall: 10 to 20 cm. Locations: most of Nova Scotia, including Halifax Metro. Time span: Friday evening until Saturday afternoon. Remarks: Snow will begin spreading across western Nova Scotia late Friday afternoon, and then across the rest of the province Friday night. The snow will taper off from west to east during the day Saturday. Latest forecast guidance suggests that accumulations of 10 to 20 cm are possible. As this system develops further and approaches the Maritimes, snowfall warnings may be issued. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of very cold wind chills is expected. Wind chills near -50 continue to affect Arctic Bay and Pond Inlet. Clyde River will experience these same extreme wind chills tonight and Friday. Conditions will begin to moderate across the region on Saturday. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-19T09:45:27-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-18T17:46:27-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0321288643.2021
Area: Arctic Bay, Pond Inlet, Clyde River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A snow squall is impacting parts of Oakville and Mississauga. Hazards: DANGEROUS whiteout conditions. Source: Weather RADAR and Highway Webcams. Weather spotters have also reported whiteout conditions in the area. Locations impacted include: Oakville, Clarkson, Bronte Creek Provincial Park, Trafalgar, Bronte and Glenorchy. This includes the following highways: -Highway 407 between Trafalgar Road and Walkers Line -Highway 403/Queen Elizabeth Way between Ford Drive and Walkers Line DANGEROUS whiteout conditions are being observed on major highways in Oakville and south Mississauga. Remember, see snow drive slow. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls may develop tonight and continue into Friday. Travel along Highway 17 between Marathon and Wawa may become hazardous due to heavy snow and poor visibility. Accumulations in excess of 15 cm are possible, although the shifting nature of the snow bands may limit accumulations somewhat. At this point, it appears that the heaviest amounts will occur south of Highway 17. The snow squalls should move east of the region by late Friday. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
